title: Morning Agenda: Valeant Losses Drag Ackman Hedge Fund Down
fulltext:
VALEANT LOSSES DRAG ACKMAN HEDGE FUND DOWN|Pershing Square Holdings, the publicly listed entity of William A. Ackman’s
                                                    firm, reported ayear-to-date loss of 25.2 percentas of March 22,Alexandra Stevenson reports in DealBook.
Most of the losses stem from Mr. Ackman’s bet on Valeant Pharmaceuticals, whose stock has fallen 67 percent so far this year. Mr. Ackman’s commitment to Valeant has not wavered and he even
                                                    sold part of his stake in Mondelez, partly to free up cash.
Mr. Ackman is not the only investor taking heat for a bullish call on Valeant. The hedge fund managerJohn A. Paulson held a conference call last week to deal with investor concernsabout his 13.2
                                                    million-share position in Valeant. Mr. Paulson said that he had no plans to sell his holdings or buy more stock.
Valeant’s biggest shareholder, Ruane, Cunniff & Goldfarb, has announced that its chief executive, Robert Goldfarb, would retire after the steep losses from Valeant.“While we have
                                                    beaten the market over the past decade, through the end of 2015, our investment in Valeant has diminished a record that we have built over two generations and in which we take great pride,” the
                                                    firm told investors.
Valeant itself is in a difficult situation because its former chief financial officer, Howard B. Schiller, refuses to leave quietly,Steven Davidoff Solomon writes in Deal Professor.
The company accused Mr. Schiller of “improper conduct,” but he might be sticking around for an uncomfortably long time.A Valeant director can be removed only by shareholders either acting at the annual meeting or by special resolution.Still, Mr. Schiller will be busy as both he and the departing chief executive may face pay clawback actions.
Valeant has been incorporated in British Columbia, Canada, since an inversion in 2010. The law there means that litigation over Valeant is unlikely to focus on whether the board breached its fiduciary duties.Instead, there would be regular stock-drop securities lawsuits.The irony is that the hedge funds that now have seats on Valeant’s board would be some of the biggest possible beneficiaries
                                                    of the litigation.

JUDGE SLAMS F.T.C. FOR TESTIMONY IN OFFICE DEPOT|A federal judge criticized the Federal Trade Commission fortrying to elicit false information from an Amazon executive during a trialin which it was trying to block Staples’ takeover of its rival Office Depot,Bloomberg News reports.
Judge Emmet G. Sullivan of the District Court for the District of Columbia said during the trial that it was “very disturbing” when the United States tried to persuade a witness “to
                                                    say something for the benefit of the United States of America that is not true.”
Prentis Wilson, a vice president of a new Amazon unit that sells office supplies to companies, had declined to comment under oath about a written statement.His testimony was central to the claim that Amazon would be a formidable competitor to an enlarged Staples.The F.T.C. argued that Staples and Office Depot would dominate the market and the merger would lead to higher prices for corporate customers.
Tara Reinhart, a lawyer for the commission, said that the agency never asked Mr. Wilson to say something that was not true.

ON THE AGENDA|The Commerce Department will publish data ondurable goods ordersfor February at 8:30 a.m.James Bullard,
                                                    the president of the St. Louis Fed, will speak at the New York Association for Business Economics at 8:15 a.m.

CREDIT SUISSE CHIEF SAYS RISKY BETS WERE A ‘SURPRISE’|According to Tidjane Thiam, the chief, a thirst for revenue
                                                    “at all costs” drove traders at Credit Suisse to take large, risky positions, catching top executives off guard andforcing them to accelerate cost-cutting,Chad Bray and Liz Moyer report in DealBook.
Trading conditions have been unfavorable and Credit Suisse has suffered from its “outsized” positions in risky, hard-to-sell securities.
Credit Suisse also plans to shrink its investment bank further.The bank said it planned to eliminate 2,000 jobs in the trading arm of its investment bank as part of 6,000 job cuts across the company.
                                                    It also said it would exit some businesses.
Mr. Thiam said the size of positions on the bank’s trading book“was a surprise for a number of people and was not a widely known fact.”Top executives, including himself, became
                                                    aware of them only in January — months after they first outlined a plan to refocus the company on less volatile businesses.
“It’s unfortunate. And I think it’s also indicative of an attitude to risk that has to change,” he said. He added later thatthe traders had not acted improperly, but that
                                                    the limits on the positions kept being raised over time.
Investors now have a light at the end of the tunnel,George Hay writes in Breakingviews.
                                                    But it has taken too long for Mr. Thiam to reach this point.
Credit Suisse said that it would add $821 million to what it expected to take off its cost base by 2018. This could have been done five months ago and without the embarrassing episodes that have arisen along
                                                    the way.The bank is heading in the right direction, but from the back foot, Mr. Hay writes.

|The DealBook newsletter will take a break on Friday and return on Monday.

|Contactamie.tsang@nytimes.com

Yum Said to Hold Talks With K.K.R. on Sale of China Business|Yum Brands has started discussions with financial firms, including
                                                    K.K.R. and Baring Private Equity Asia, about selling as much as 20 percent of the business in China, The Wall Street Journal reports, citing people familiar with the situation.the wall street journal

Lawmakers Raise Concerns About ChemChina’s Purchase of Syngenta|Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa delivered a public
                                                    broadside against China National Chemical Corporation’s planned deal, saying that the government must ensure that “we’re not permitting the sale of too much of our food industry,
                                                    especially when government-controlled entities like ChemChina are the buyers.”the wall street journal

HSBC Adds Former Chief Executive of Standard Life to Board|The appointment of the former chief, David Nish, comes as the British
                                                    lender continues to shake up its board before it names a successor to its chairman.NYT »

Bank of America Settles Claims It Cheated Merrill Trainees Out of Overtime|Bank of America and its Merrill Lynch unit will pay
                                                    $14 million to settle lawsuits claiming that they forced financial adviser trainees to work at least 60 hours a week, including on weekends, without paying them overtime.reuters

Turning Problems Into Profit in High-Finance Play|Claire Danes and John Krasinski are rival partners at a private equity firm
                                                    in Sarah Burgess’s play about shenanigans in the world of big money.NYT »

Starboard Value Plans to Oust Yahoo’s Board|The activist hedge fund will announce as soon as Thursday that it will put
                                                    up a slate of nine directors for the Internet company.NYT »

Longtime Deal Maker at Blackstone Eyes $1 Billion I.P.O.|The deal maker, Chinh Chu, who ended a 25-year career at Blackstone Group
                                                    last year, is preparing to introduce an acquisition company that could raise up to $1 billion in an initial public offering, Reuters reports, citing people familiar with the matter.reuters

The Uber Model, It Turns Out, Doesn’t Translate|The ride-hailing service Uber is a giant, but companies that aim to get
                                                    stuff done on demand for customers, like food delivery, grocery shopping and parking, are faltering, Farhad Manjoo writes in State of the Art.State of the Art »

Uber and OlaCab Clash in Court in India|In a lawsuit filed in the Delhi High Court, Uber has lodged a complaint saying that Ola
                                                    employees created some 93,000 fake user accounts, through which they made more than 400,000 bookings, summoning Uber drivers to fetch passengers, who never materialized.the financial times

S.E.C. Orders Exxon Mobil Shareholder Vote on Climate Data|A resolution, if approved, would force the energy giant to outline
                                                    for investors how its profitability may be affected by climate change.NYT »

Ex-Trader Tom Hayes Ordered to Pay $1.2 Million in Libor Case|Mr. Hayes was the first person to go to trial in Britain and be
                                                    convicted on criminal charges related to the manipulation of the benchmark interest rate.NYT »

Judge Orders Extradition to U.S. in ‘Flash Crash’ Case|Navinder Singh Sarao, a British trader, is accused by American
                                                    authorities of contributing to turmoil that led the Dow to fall more than 600 points.NYT »

Advertising Industry Wrestles With Bias After a Lawsuit|A conference in Miami aimed at charting the industry’s future was
                                                    instead heavy with discussion about sexism in the workplace.NYT »

Fitness Entrepreneur Pleads Guilty in Wire Fraud Case|Joshua B. Newman, a fitness entrepreneur, bilked at least 30 investors out
                                                    of about $3.1 million, authorities said.NYT »

Novartis to Settle S.E.C.’s China Bribe Case for $25 Million|Novartis, the Swiss drug maker, said that it agreed to pay
                                                    $25 million to settle a case by the Securities and Exchange Commission that claimed that the company paid bribes to health professionals in China to increase sales from 2009 to 2013.bloomberg news

F.B.I. Clash With Apple Loosed a Torrent of Possible Ways to Hack an iPhone|The prominence of the case has stimulated people worldwide
                                                    to try to get into the device, and now the government has to check out their ideas.NYT »

Amaya Chief Faces Charges of Insider Trading|Quebec’s securities regulator charged the chief executive of the online gambling
                                                    giant Amaya and two of his associates with insider trading over the company’s takeover of PokerStars in 2014.the wall street journal

title: Morning Agenda: Start-Up Investors Are Not Waiting for Growth
fulltext:
START-UP INVESTORS ARE NOT WAITING FOR GROWTH|Investors may be throwing money at mature start-ups like Uber and Airbnb at soaring
                                                    valuations, butthe venture capitalists who can pick a winner early onare the ones who come out on top,Katie Benner and Michael J. de la Merced report in The New York Times.
CB Insights, a research firm, created a list of thetop 20 venture capitalistsworldwide and three-quarters
                                                    of them areinvestors who put money into early rounds of financing.
The list includes Peter Fenton of Benchmark, who invested in Twitter when it had only 25 employees; and Jim Goetz at Sequoia Capital, who invested in WhatsApp before Facebook acquired it.
Early-stage investments have accounted for the lion’s share of gains made in the venture industry since 1994, according to Cambridge Associates, a research firm that studied the financial reports
                                                    of dozens of venture firms.
But the value of early investment has been obscured in recent years by nontraditional start-up investors piling into private technology companies when they are already proven growth stories.
Rebecca Lynn, a managing director and co-founder at Canvas Ventures who is on the CB Insights list, said early-stage investments pay off more because theinvestors get more of an ownership stake and are more a part of the team.
                                                    “Later-stage investing is more like a stock bet,” she said. “You’re along for the ride.”

CHINESE OWNER OF WALDORF ASTORIA BETS ON HIGH-END LODGING|Not content with acquiring the Art Deco glamour of the Waldorf Astoria,
                                                    Anbang Insurance Group has clinched a deal to buy Strategic Hotels and Resorts,Amie Tsang reports in DealBook.
The deal to buy the real estate investment trust from Blackstone wasvalued at $6.5 billion, according to a person with knowledge of the deal who was not authorized to comment.
The deal would give the Chinese insurance company ownership of the Four Seasons hotels and resorts in Silicon Valley, Washington and Jackson Hole, Wyo., as well as the JW Marriott Essex House Hotel near
                                                    Central Park in Manhattan.
The agreement is a quick turnaround for Blackstone, which struck a deal to buy Strategic Hotels just six months ago, for $6 billion including debt.
The deal, which was earlier reported by Bloomberg, comes after Anbang bought the Waldorf two years ago, saying it was looking to North America for stable returns on real estate.

ON THE AGENDA|TheAmerican Bankers AssociationGovernment Relations Summit starts at 7:45 a.m. The Securities and Exchange
                                                    Commission will hold an open meeting on the 2016budget of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Boardat 10 a.m.TheSecurities Industry and Financial Markets Associationis holding
                                                    its annual compliance and legal society seminar this week and theInvestment Company Instituteis also holding its Mutual Funds and Investment Management Conference.

MARKET DOUBTS ABOUT THE DEAL WITH PFIZER|Pfizer and Allergan have not managed to convince the stock market that their pending
                                                    deal will be concluded without major problems,Jeff Sommer writes in Strategies.
Their share prices should be converging, but the spread remains unusually wide.The problem is that tax inversions do not hold the same appeal for everyone as they do for people in corner offices.
President Obama said they were “unpatriotic” and the Treasury has tightened its regulations twice in two years to make them less appealing. Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew has also said that
                                                    he intended to tighten the rules.
Big money is at stake.Using Pfizer’s latest filings, Mr. Sommer calculated that the company had more than $160 billion parked overseas, which enabled it to avoid or defer billions in tax payments
                                                    to the United States.
The billions of tax dollars up for grabs have turned this deal into apolitical flash pointand made it risky. The government might intervene. If it can’t stop the merger, it might make it
                                                    economically unappealing.
Whether Pfizer would have more flexibility in using its overseas cash after the merger is an important question for the markets, but the answer is still unclear.
Treasury, which is expected to issue new rules in the next few weeks, says that legislation would be required to stop inversions entirely, although the passage of several pending bills is unlikely this year.
                                                    Corporate tax rules might be overhauled, but it is uncertain when that might occur.
At the same time, the deal is being scrutinized by regulators and the stock market, wherethe shares of both companies have been battered.

|Contactamie.tsang@nytimes.com

China Vanke Lines Up Rail Deal in Face of Ownership Tussle|China Vanke, the property developer enmeshed in a prominent takeover
                                                    battle, said it planned to acquire a stake worth an estimated $6.2 billion to $9.3 billion in Shenzhen Metro as part of a long-promised restructuring.the financial times

Bankers Who Have Been Submitted to Watch List of British Regulator|Under the new Financial Conduct Authority rules, London’s
                                                    biggest international banks have put forward nearly 250 executives who risk fines or bans from the industry unless they can show they took all reasonable steps to prevent wrongdoing within their team.the financial times

Valeant, Woes Rising, Backs Away From Boldness to Calm Investors|Valeant, a drug maker, which made big profits by raising the
                                                    price of old drugs, is now talking about investing in research and paying down debt as its stock price slumps.NYT »

China Zheshang Bank Said to Seek $1.75 Billion from I.P.O.|China Zheshang Bank, a commercial lender in eastern China, and China’s
                                                    National Social Security Fund are offering 3.3 billion shares at 3.92 Hong Kong dollars to 4.12 Hong Kong dollars each, according to terms for the deal obtained by Bloomberg.bloomberg news

Bank of Tianjin Said to Seek to Raise at Least $950 Million in I.P.O.|Bank of Tianjin, a commercial lender, plans to sell about
                                                    $560 million of stock to seven cornerstone investors in its Hong Kong initial public offering, Bloomberg News reports, citing people with knowledge of the matter.BLOOMBERG NEWS

Sequoia Partner Leaves in Face of Accusations of Sex Abuse|Sequoia Capital said it parted ways with Michael Goguen, a longtime
                                                    partner, in the wake of accusations, which he denies, of sexual abuse and a failure to follow through on a $40 million settlement.the wall street journal

Alibaba Affiliate Attracts Investors|Cainiao, Alibaba’s delivery affiliate, attracted investment from Temasek Holdings
                                                    and GIC in its first round of external fund-raising since its creation in 2013.bloomberg news

Cambridge Epigenetix Secures $29 Million of Financing|Cambridge Epigenetix, which seeks to exploit a way of switching genes on
                                                    and off, has raised financing from venture funds including Google’s GV, Wellcome Trust’s Syncona, Sequoia Capital, New Science Ventures and Cambridge Enterprise.the financial times

Democrats’ Bills to Empower Puerto Rico Face Uphill Battle|Elements of the bills will probably meet stiff opposition from
                                                    Republicans, who have expressed concern over any islandwide debt restructuring.NYT »

Fed’s Plans to Raise Interest Rates Are Delayed, Not Derailed|The challenge is to forge consensus among Federal Reserve
                                                    officials about when to resume the march begun in December, when the central bank raised rates for the first time since the financial crisis.NYT »

Culture Gap Impedes U.S. Business Efforts for Trade With Cuba|As President Obama prepares to visit Cuba this month, the lack of
                                                    trade with the former foe threatens to sap momentum from the process of building relations.NYT »

China Weighs Letting Banks Sell Bad Debt to Investors|The tentative proposal, which officials said on Saturday would be modest
                                                    in scale, is meant to help alleviate one of the major drags on China’s economy.NYT »

In the Apple Case, a Debate Over Data Hits Home|The debate that began three years ago after revelations about government surveillance
                                                    has become more personal, now that smartphones are involved.NYT »

WhatsApp Encryption Said to Stymie Wiretap Order|A fight with WhatsApp, the world’s largest mobile messaging service, would
                                                    open a new front in the Obama administration’s dispute with Silicon Valley over encryption, security and privacy.NYT »|Obama, at South by Southwest, Calls for Law Enforcement Access in Encryption Fight

Cautious Reception for Head of China’s Securities Regulation|Liu Shiyu, the 54-year-old former banker who gave a cautious
                                                    inaugural news conference as chairman of the China Securities Regulatory Commission on Saturday, still has to show whether he can tackle the fundamental problems that make Chinese shares so volatile,
                                                    some investors said.the wall street journal
